headline.main: After Terrorist Attacks, Army Rethinks Priorities On Fighting and Spending
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MILITARY BUDGET

lead_paragraph: During a long, hot summer of Pentagon budget battles, whispers in the corridors said 2 of the Army's 10 active divisions were headed to the chopping block to free money for the military's future weapons. Ground forces would have little utility in the sort of brief conflicts envisioned by some Pentagon strategists for coming years, and long-range precision weapons launched by air and sea could handle the job.
abstract: Terrorist attacks on Sept 11 and war in Afghanistan cause Pentagon to rethink earlier plans to streamline Army; officials say success of war in Afghanistan will depend on ground operations, whether fought by proxy army of Afghans aided by American special-operations forces or eventually joined by American and allied combat units engaging directly in the fight (M)
